citeinfo.title: Synoptic carbon gas fluxes from streams, rivers, and lakes in the conterminous US, USGS Landcarbon, 2012 to 2014

descript.abstract: In support of the USGS LandCarbon project, field observations of stream and lake carbon gas fluxes and other water-quality data were collected from surface waters in the conterminous US. The sampling was designed to cover a variety of geographic, climatic, and environmental settings to better understand the ranges and distributions of carbon gas fluxes from surface waters. Field observations of carbon gas concentration and flux were paired with laboratory measurements of stream chemical characteristics.Locations were derived from field GPS values or from listed coordinates of USGS streamgages located at the sampling site. Discharge data was either measured in the field at the time of sample collection or downloaded from streamgage data (waterdata.usgs.gov/nwis). Laboratory values were analyzed in the USGS office located in Boulder, CO.The missing values occur in the database for several field observations. Missing values occurred when the site was not appropriate for that parameter (i.e. stream discharge in a lake or reservoir) or due to equipment malfunction.
descript.purpose: These data were compiled to provide summary information about current and historical USGS streamgages in the conterminous United States. The USGS has several programs (including the National Water-Quality Assessment Program and the National Streamflow Information Program) that need the summary data for improvement of study design and analysis.

procstep.procdesc: The steps used to generate the dataset are listed below.1. Field observations were made at sampling locations and surface water was collected for subsequent laboratory analysis.2. Water samples were filtered and preserved on-site and shipped to the USGS Boulder, CO laboratory for analysis.3. Laboratory analyses were performed using appropriate QA/QC procedures.4. Raw field and laboratory results were combined into tables.5. Unit conversion and other calculations were performed using SAS 9.4 and relevant data was exported using built-in scripts.6. Exported data was checked for completeness and consistency and saved as a comma-delimited file.7. Data were subjected to USGS review and placed on USGS Science Base for public access.

attr.attrdef: Carbon dioxide gas exchange velocity, absolute value, meters per day.
attr.attrdefs: Derived from field observations of CO2_flux and CO2_um assuming CO2_flux occurs as Fickian diffusion such that kCO2 = CO2_flux / (CO2_um - CO2_a), where CO2_a is carbon dioxide conentration at atmospheric equilibrium assuming at atmospheric concentration of 390 ppm.

attr.attrdef: Instantaneous water-to-atmosphere oxygen flux, moles per square meter per day.
attr.attrdefs: Derived from field observations of oxygen concentration (o2_mgl) and abs_kCO2. The value was calculated as O2_flux_inst = (O2w - O2a) x (abs_kCO2 x [(ScO2 / ScCO2)^-0.67]). ScO2 and ScCO2 are the temperature-dependent Schmidt numbers for oxygen and carbon dioxide, respectively. (O2w - O2a) is the molar difference between observed dissolved oxygen concentrations and atmospheric equilibrium oxygen concentration. O2w was calculated from o2_mgl and O2a was calculated from waterTemp and atmP.
